questionTask.text: What information is required in the Application to Lease or Rent form?
What is the purpose of the Notice Regarding Background Investigation Reports Pursuant to California Law?
What is the role of a real estate broker in real estate transactions according to the form?

statementsTask.text:
The Application to Lease or Rent form requires the applicant to provide their personal information, rental history, employment information, and financial information. The applicant must also indicate whether they are applying as a tenant, tenant with co-tenant(s), or guarantor/co-signor. The form also requires the applicant to authorize the Housing Provider to verify the information provided, obtain a credit report, and an “Investigative Consumer Report” (“ICR”) on and about the applicant. Additionally, the applicant must provide a copy of their driver's license or other acceptable identification upon request, and authorize the Housing Provider to disclose information to prior, current, or subsequent owners and/or agents with whom the applicant has had, or intends to have, a rental relationship. Finally, the applicant must provide screening information and fee directly to the Housing Provider's authorized screening service.

Sources:
[0] APPLICATION TO LEASE OR RENT/SCREENING FEE (LRA PAGE 3 OF 3)
[1] APPLICATION TO LEASE OR RENT/SCREENING FEE (LRA PAGE 1 OF 3)
[2] Applicant is completing Application to Lease or Rent as a (check one) tenant, tenant with co-tenant(s) or guarantor/co-signor.
[3] Applicant further authorizes Housing Provider to disclose information to prior, current, or subsequent owners and/or agents with whom applicant has had, or intends to have, a rental relationship.
[4] Applicant submits this application to lease or rent for the Premises located at 40 W. 3RD AVE., #903, SAN MATEO, CA  94402  ("Premises") or any prospective locations which may fit Applicant's rental criteria.
[5] Applicant represents the above information to be true and complete, and hereby authorizes Housing Provider to: (i) verify the information provided; and (ii) obtain a credit report on applicant and (iii) obtain an “Investigative Consumer Report” (“ICR”) on and about applicant.

The Application to Lease or Rent form requires the applicant to check whether they are a tenant, tenant with co-tenant(s), or guarantor/co-signor [1]. The form also requires the full name of the applicant [2], their date of birth [3], driver's license number [4], and social security number/tax identification numbers (which are found in section II, 4) [5]. The form indicates that there are two total applicants [6] and asks for the names and relationships of all other proposed occupants [7]. Additionally, the form asks for information about the applicant's car, including make, model, year, and license number [8]. The form also asks whether the applicant has been a party to an unlawful detainer action or filed bankruptcy within the last seven years [9], whether the applicant or any proposed occupant has ever been asked to move out of a residence [10], and whether the applicant or any proposed occupant has ever been convicted of or pleaded no contest to a felony within the last seven years [11]. The form also asks for the applicant's employment gross income [12] [13] and requires the applicant to pay a nonrefundable screening fee of $45.00 per applicant [14]. If the application is received without the full screening fee, the housing provider will not process the application and will return the application and any portion of the screening fee paid [15]. Finally, the form requires the applicant to acknowledge receipt of the attached NOTICE REGARDING BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION PURSUANT TO CALIFORNIA LAW [16] and indicates that the landlord intends to obtain information about the applicant from an investigative consumer reporting agency and/or a consumer credit reporting agency for the purpose of letting a dwelling [17].

Sources:
[1] Applicant is completing Application to Lease or Rent as a (check one) tenant, tenant with co-tenant(s) or guarantor/co-signor.
[2] FULL NAME OF APPLICANT
[3] Date of Birth _______________________________ (For purpose of obtaining credit reports.
[4] (1) Driver's License No.
[5] See section II, 4 for Social Security Number/Tax Identification Numbers.
[6] Total number of applicants 2.
[7] Name(s) of all other proposed occupant(s) and relationship to applicant
[8] Auto: Make  Model  Year  License No.
[9] Has applicant been a party to an unlawful detainer action or filed bankruptcy within the last seven years?............
[10] Has applicant or any proposed occupant ever been asked to move out of a residence?.........................................
[11] Has applicant or any proposed occupant ever been convicted of or pleaded no contest to a felony within the last seven years?
[12] Employment gross income $
[13] Employment gross income $
[14] X  Applicant shall pay a nonrefundable screening fee of $45.00  per applicant, directly to Housing Provider, applied as follows: (Civil Code Section 1950.6 sets the maximum screening fee that can be charged, as adjusted annually by the Consumer Price Index.
[15] If 2B is selected, and the application is received without the full screening fee: (i) Housing Provider will notify Applicant, (ii) the application will not be processed, and (iii) the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned.
[16] By signing below, you also acknowledge receipt of the attached NOTICE REGARDING BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION PURSUANT TO CALIFORNIA LAW (C.A.R.
[17] WEI WANG LING  (the “Landlord”) intends to obtain information about you from an investigative consumer reporting agency and/or a consumer credit reporting agency for the purpose letting a dwelling.

The Notice Regarding Background Investigation Reports Pursuant to California Law is a document that acknowledges the receipt of a notice regarding background investigation reports. The notice informs the recipient that they may be the subject of investigative consumer reports and consumer credit reports obtained for housing purposes. The purpose of the notice is to inform the recipient that they have the right to find out what is in the investigative consumer report file on them with proper identification. The landlord is required to provide a copy of the investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law. The notice also informs the recipient that the source of any investigative consumer report will be disclosed.

Sources:
[0] NOTICE REGARDING BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION REPORTS PURSUANT TO CALIFORNIA LAW
[1] Under California Code Civil Code section 1786.22, you are entitled to find out from a CRA what is in the ICRA's file on you with proper identification, as follows:
[2] With respect to any investigative consumer report from an investigative consumer reporting agency (“CRA”), the Landlord may investigate the information contained in your rental application and other background information about you, including but not limited to obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, your social security number, and other information about you, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about you.
[3] Thus, you can expect to be the subject of “investigative consumer reports” and “consumer credit reports” obtained for housing purposes.

The Notice Regarding Background Investigation Reports Pursuant to California Law is intended to inform the individual that the landlord intends to obtain information about them from an investigative consumer reporting agency and/or a consumer credit reporting agency for the purpose of letting a dwelling [1] [2]. The reports may include information about the individual's character, general reputation, personal characteristics, and mode of living [3]. The notice also informs the individual that they have the right to receive a copy of an investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law [4]. Additionally, the notice outlines the process for requesting a summary of all information contained in the CRA's file on the individual, which includes providing proper identification and prepaying any toll charges for a telephone call or requesting a copy be sent by certified mail [5] [6]. The notice also specifies that CRAs complying with requests for certified mailings shall not be liable for disclosures to third parties caused by mishandling of mail after such mailings leave the CRAs [7]. The notice further explains what constitutes proper identification, and that the CRA may require additional information to verify the individual's identity if they cannot identify themselves with the provided information [8] [9]. The CRA is required to provide trained personnel to explain any information furnished to the individual and provide a written explanation of any coded information contained in files maintained on them [10] [11]. The individual may be accompanied by one other person of their choosing, who must furnish reasonable identification, and the CRA may require a written statement granting permission to discuss the file in such person's presence [12] [13]. Finally, the notice specifies that the CRA may not charge the individual more than the actual copying costs for providing them with a copy of their file [14] [15]. Therefore, the purpose of the Notice Regarding Background Investigation Reports Pursuant to California Law is to inform individuals of their rights and the process for obtaining information from a CRA for housing purposes.

Sources:
[1] WEI WANG LING  (the “Landlord”) intends to obtain information about you from an investigative consumer reporting agency and/or a consumer credit reporting agency for the purpose letting a dwelling.
[2] Thus, you can expect to be the subject of “investigative consumer reports” and “consumer credit reports” obtained for housing purposes.
[3] Such reports may include information about your character, general reputation, personal characteristics and mode of living.
[4] The Landlord agrees to provide you with a copy of an investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law.
[5] A summary of all information contained in the CRA's file on you that is required to be provided by the California Civil Code will be provided to you via telephone, if you have made a written request, with proper identification, for telephone disclosure, and the toll charge, if any, for the telephone call is prepaid by or charged directly to you.
[6] By requesting a copy be sent to a specified addressee by certified mail.
[7] CRAs complying with requests for certified mailings shall not be liable for disclosures to third parties caused by mishandling of mail after such mailings leave the CRAs.
[8] “Proper Identification” includes documents such as a valid driver's license, social security account number, military identification card, and credit cards.
[9] Only if you cannot identify yourself with such information may the CRA require additional information concerning your employment and personal or family history in order to verify your identity.
[10] The CRA will provide trained personnel to explain any information furnished to you and will provide a written explanation of any coded information contained in files maintained on you.
[11] This written explanation will be provided whenever a file is provided to you for visual inspection.
[12] You may be accompanied by one other person of your choosing, who must furnish reasonable identification.
[13] A CRA may require you to furnish a written statement granting permission to the CRA to discuss your file in such person's presence.
[14] The CRA may not charge you more than the actual copying costs for providing you with a copy of your file.
[15] NOTICE REGARDING BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION REPORTS PURSUANT TO CALIFORNIA LAW

According to the sources, a real estate broker is the person qualified to advise on real estate transactions. The form made available to real estate professionals through an agreement with or purchase from the California Association of REALTORS® is not intended to identify the user as a REALTOR®. Therefore, the role of a real estate broker in real estate transactions is to provide advice and guidance to clients.

Sources:
[0] A REAL ESTATE BROKER IS THE PERSON QUALIFIED TO ADVISE ON REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS.
[1] A REAL ESTATE BROKER IS THE PERSON QUALIFIED TO ADVISE ON REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS.
[2] This form is made available to real estate professionals through an agreement with or purchase from the California Association of REALTORS®.
[3] This form is made available to real estate professionals through an agreement with or purchase from the California Association of REALTORS®.
[4] It is not intended to identify the user as a REALTOR®.

According to source s0, a real estate broker is the person qualified to advise on real estate transactions. Their role is to provide guidance and expertise to clients who are buying, selling, or renting properties.

The Notice Regarding Background Investigation Reports Pursuant to California Law is a document that acknowledges the receipt of a notice regarding background investigation reports. The notice informs the recipient that they may be the subject of investigative consumer reports and consumer credit reports obtained for housing purposes. The purpose of the notice is to inform the recipient that they have the right to find out what is in the investigative consumer report file on them with proper identification. The landlord is required to provide a copy of the investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law. The notice also informs the recipient that the source of any investigative consumer report will be disclosed.

qaTask.question: What is the role of a real estate broker in real estate transactions according to the form?
qaTask.answer:
According to the sources, a real estate broker is the person qualified to advise on real estate transactions. The form made available to real estate professionals through an agreement with or purchase from the California Association of REALTORS® is not intended to identify the user as a REALTOR®. Therefore, the role of a real estate broker in real estate transactions is to provide advice and guidance to clients.

qaTask.question: what happens after the application to rent is completed?
qaTask.answer:
After the application to rent is completed, the Housing Provider acknowledges receipt of the entire Application to Lease or Rent/Screening Fee (source 2). The Housing Provider may receive more than one application for the Premises and the application does not guarantee that the applicant will be offered the Premises (source 1). If the application is received without the full screening fee, the Housing Provider will notify the applicant, the application will not be processed, and the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned (source 4). The Landlord may investigate the information contained in the rental application and other background information about the applicant, including obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, social security number, and other information about the applicant, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about the applicant (source 7). If the application is not fully completed or if section II, 2 is applicable and the application is received without the full screening fee, the application will not be processed, and the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned (source 9). The Landlord agrees to provide the applicant with a copy of an investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law (source 3). The completed application and any applicable fee not already paid should be returned to the Housing Provider (source 8).

Sources:
[0] Applicant understands and agrees that: (i) this is an application to rent only and does not guarantee that applicant will be offered the Premises; (ii) Housing Provider may receive more than one application for the Premises and, (iii) Applicant will provide a copy of applicant's driver's license or other acceptable identification upon request.
[1] Housing Provider acknowledges receipt of this entire Application to Lease or Rent/Screening Fee.
[2] The Landlord agrees to provide you with a copy of an investigative consumer report when required to do so under California law.
[3] If 2B is selected, and the application is received without the full screening fee: (i) Housing Provider will notify Applicant, (ii) the application will not be processed, and (iii) the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned.
[4] With respect to any investigative consumer report from an investigative consumer reporting agency (“CRA”), the Landlord may investigate the information contained in your rental application and other background information about you, including but not limited to obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, your social security number, and other information about you, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about you.
[5] Return your completed application and any applicable fee not already paid to:

qaTask.question: what happens after the application to rent is completed?
qaTask.answer:
After completing the Application to Lease or Rent, the applicant authorizes the Housing Provider to verify the information provided, obtain a credit report, and obtain an "Investigative Consumer Report" on and about the applicant [1] [2]. The ICR may include, but not be limited to, criminal background checks, reports on unlawful detainers, bad checks, fraud warnings, and employment and tenant history [3]. If the application is not fully completed or if the screening fee is not paid in full, the application will not be processed, and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned [4] [5]. If the Housing Provider receives the application without the full screening fee, they will notify the applicant, and the application will not be processed [6].

Sources:
[1] Applicant represents the above information to be true and complete, and hereby authorizes Housing Provider to: (i) verify the information provided; and (ii) obtain a credit report on applicant and (iii) obtain an “Investigative Consumer Report” (“ICR”) on and about applicant.
[2] An ICR may include, but not be limited to, criminal background checks, reports on unlawful detainers, bad checks, fraud warnings, and employment and tenant history.
[3] An ICR may include, but not be limited to, criminal background checks, reports on unlawful detainers, bad checks, fraud warnings, and employment and tenant history.
[4] If application is not fully completed, or if section II, 2 is applicable and the application is received without the full screening fee: (i) the application will not be processed, and (ii) the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned.
[5] If 2B is selected, and the application is received without the full screening fee: (i) Housing Provider will notify Applicant, (ii) the application will not be processed, and (iii) the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned.
[6] If 2B is selected, and the application is received without the full screening fee: (i) Housing Provider will notify Applicant, (ii) the application will not be processed, and (iii) the application and any portion of the screening fee paid will be returned.

qaTask.question: how will my information be used?
qaTask.answer:
Your information may be used for various purposes such as verifying your identity, providing you with a copy of the information, explaining any coded information contained in files maintained on you, obtaining a credit report, and obtaining an “Investigative Consumer Report” (“ICR”) on and about you. The CRA may require additional information concerning your employment and personal or family history in order to verify your identity. Such reports may include information about your character, general reputation, personal characteristics, and mode of living. Proper identification includes documents such as a valid driver's license, social security account number, military identification card, and credit cards.

[3] Such reports may include information about your character, general reputation, personal characteristics and mode of living.
[4] Only if you cannot identify yourself with such information may the CRA require additional information concerning your employment and personal or family history in order to verify your identity.
[5] “Proper Identification” includes documents such as a valid driver's license, social security account number, military identification card, and credit cards.

qaTask.question: how will my information be used?
qaTask.answer:
Your information will be used for the purpose of letting a dwelling [1]. As part of this process, you can expect to be the subject of "investigative consumer reports" and "consumer credit reports" obtained for housing purposes [2]. The Landlord may investigate the information contained in your rental application and other background information about you, including but not limited to obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, your social security number, and other information about you, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about you [3]. The results of this report may be used as a factor in making housing decisions [4]. You are entitled to find out from a CRA what is in the ICRA's file on you with proper identification [5].

qaTask.question: what information will the background report include?
qaTask.answer:
The background report may include information about the individual's character, general reputation, personal characteristics, mode of living, criminal report, eviction report, work history, social security number, and other information about the individual. The report may be obtained for housing purposes and may be used as a factor in making housing decisions. The source of the investigative consumer report will be disclosed, and the individual may request a copy of the information in person. The CRA will provide trained personnel to explain any information furnished to the individual and will provide a written explanation of any coded information contained in files maintained on the individual.

qaTask.question: what information will the background report include?
qaTask.answer:
The background report may include information about the tenant's character, general reputation, personal characteristics, and mode of living [1] [2]. The report may also include a criminal report, eviction report, verification of references and work history, and interviews with people who are knowledgeable about the tenant [3]. The purpose of obtaining this information is to make housing decisions [4].

Sources:
[1] Such reports may include information about your character, general reputation, personal characteristics and mode of living.
[2] With respect to any investigative consumer report from an investigative consumer reporting agency (“CRA”), the Landlord may investigate the information contained in your rental application and other background information about you, including but not limited to obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, your social security number, and other information about you, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about you.
[3] With respect to any investigative consumer report from an investigative consumer reporting agency (“CRA”), the Landlord may investigate the information contained in your rental application and other background information about you, including but not limited to obtaining a criminal report, eviction report, verifying references, work history, your social security number, and other information about you, and interviewing people who are knowledgeable about you.
[4] the results of this report may be used as a factor in making housing decisions.
